Command or Action
enable Example: Router> enable
configure terminal Example: Router# configure terminal
crypto ipsec transform-set transform-set-name transform [transform2...transform4] Example: Router(config)# crypto ipsec transform-set gdoi-trans esp-aes esp-sha-hmac
crypto ipsec profile ipsec-profile-name Example: Router(config)# crypto ipsec profile profile1
set transform-set transform-set-name Example: Router(ipsec-profile)# set transform-set transformset1
exit Example: Router(ipsec-profile)# exit
crypto gdoi group group-name Example: Router(config)# crypto gdoi group gdoigroupname

Enter one of the following commands: identity number number identity address ipv4 address Example: Router(config-gdoi-group)# identity number 3333 Example: Router(config-gdoi-group)# identity address ipv4 209.165.200.225
server local Example: Router(config-gdoi-group)# server local
sa ipsec sequence-number Example: Router(gdoi-local-server)# sa ipsec 1
profile ipsec-profile-name Example: Router(gdoi-sa-ipsec)# profile gdoi-p
match address ipv4 {access-list-number | access-list-name} Example: Router(gdoi-sa-ipsec)# match address ipv4 102
end Example: Router(gdoi-sa-ipsec)# end
Purpose
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Enters global configuration mode.
Defines a transform set--an acceptable combination of security protocols and algorithms.
Defines an IPsec profile and enters crypto ipsec profile configuration mode.
Specifies which transform sets can be used with the crypto map entry.
Exits IPsec profile configuration mode.
Identifies a GDOI group and enters GDOI group configuration mode.
Identifies a GDOI group number or address.
Designates a device as a GDOI key server and enters GDOI local server configuration mode.
Specifies the IPsec SA policy information to be used for a GDOI group and enters GDOI SA IPsec configuration mode.
Defines the IPsec SA policy for a GDOI group.
Specifies an IP extended access list for a GDOI registration.
Exits GDOI SA IPsec configuration mode and returns to privileged EXEC mode.
pageTitle: Cisco Group Encrypted Transport VPN Configuration Guide, Cisco IOS XE Release 3S - Cisco Group Encrypted Transport VPN [Cisco ASR 1000 Series Aggregation Services Routers] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {29320=IPsec is a well-known RFC that defines an architecture to provide various security services for traffic at the IP layer. The components and how they fit together with each other and into the IP environment are described in IETF RFC 2401., 501739=RFC 2401, 22137=In Cisco IOS XE Release 3.5S and earlier releases, key servers are not supported on the Cisco ASR 1000 series routers. They must be configured using Cisco IOS T-based or mainline-based images. This is not a restriction on Cisco IOS XE Release 3.6S and newer releases., 12487=In Cisco IOS XE Release 3.13S and earlier releases, to ensure normal traffic flow for a GET VPN configuration on Cisco ASR 1000 Series Aggregation Services Routers, a TBAR window-size of greater than 20 seconds is recommended., 117468=The policy change occurs at 1000 seconds before the current TEK lifetime expires., 120378=The group member sends encrypted traffic between host C and host D using old SAs (3DES) for 1000 seconds until its TEK lifetime expires., 222080=Generates RSA keys that will be used to sign rekey messages. You are prompted to confirm the length (in bits) of the keys to be generated. Length of less than 2048 is not recommended., 118122=Group member continues to use the old SA (3DES) for 1000 seconds until it expires., 119499=The policy change occurs 1000 seconds before the current TEK lifetime expires., 432366=With CSCsi82594, if Time-based Anti-Replay (TBAR) is enabled, the rekey time period is set to 2 hours (7200 seconds). In this scenario, the Key Server periodically sends a rekey to the Group Members every 2 hours (7200 seconds). In the below example, even though the Traffic Encryption Key (TEK) lifetime is set to 28800 seconds (8 hours), the rekey timer is still 2 hours. For show outputs displaying TBAR information, use the show crypto gdoi gm replay and show crypto gdoi ks replay commands., 519064=In Cisco IOS XE Release 3.6S, this feature was introduced on the Cisco ASR 1000 Series Aggregation Services Routers.}
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 3.    crypto key generate rsa general-keys label name-of-key 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS To configure RSA keys that will be used to sign rekey messages, perform the following steps. Omit this subtask if rekey is not in use. Security threats, as well as the cryptographic technologies to help protect against them, are constantly changing. For more information about the latest Cisco cryptographic recommendations, see the Next Generation Encryption (NGE) white paper. Note Configuring RSA Keys to Sign Rekey Messages Before creating the GDOI group, you must first configure IKE and the IPsec transform set, and you must create an IPsec profile. For information about how to configure IKE and the IPsec transform set and to create an IPsec profile, see the “Related Documents” subsection of the “Additional References” section. Prerequisites Configuring a Key Server
textAfterTable: Step 5 server local Example:  Router(config-gdoi-group)# server local   Designates a device as a GDOI key server and enters GDOI local server configuration mode.   Step 6 sa receive-only Example:  Router(config-local-server)# sa receive-only   Specifies that an IPsec SA is to be installed by a group member as “inbound only.”   What to Do Next Remove the receive-only configuration on the key server so that the group members are now operating in bidirectional receive and send mode. Configuring the Rekey This section includes the following optional tasks: Rekey is used in the control plane by the key server to periodically refresh the policy and IPsec SAs of the group. On the group-member side, instead of fully re-registering when timers expire for any other reasons, refreshing the registration with a rekey is more efficient. The initial registration is always a unicast registration. The key server can be configured to send rekeys in unicast or multicast mode. The rekey transport mode is determined by whether the key
